newsitem.title: GERMANY: Netanyahu ready for new summit with Arafat,Clinton.
newsitem.headline: Netanyahu ready for new summit with Arafat,Clinton.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Friday he was prepared to meet Palestinian President Yasser Arafat and U.S. President Bill Clinton for a Camp David-style summit on the Middle East peace process.

"As soon as the violence against us stops we can clear up all outstanding questions in six months," Netanyahu told Germany's ARD television in an interview, according to a German translation of his remarks in English.

"If we don't manage that within that time then Arafat, President Clinton and I can try to settle the Israeli-Palestinian dispute in a sort of Camp David summit. I think that is more constructive than telling us: you should not build in your capital."
Netanyahu on Thursday signalled "no deal" to any halt to Jewish settlement on occupied land, the issue that has sparked a recent wave of tension and clashes in the region.

He has also accused Arafat of failing to do enough to prevent a resumption of suicide bomb attacks by Moslem militants. Three Israeli women were killed in a bombing in Tel Aviv on March 21 and two Palestinians died in botched bombings on Tuesday.
"We don't expect 100 percent results from Arafat, but we expect 100 percent effort," Netanyahu said. "But there was no such effort, there was a 'green light' for the bombs."
He is due to meet Clinton on Monday for talks aimed at rescuing Middle East peace. Israel has demanded the Palestinian Authority crack down on "terrorism" as a condition for negotiating again.
Palestinians insist peace talks can only restart when Israel stops work on a new settlement in Arab East Jerusalem, where Israel broke the ground for 6,500 homes for Jews two weeks ago.

Palestinians have not ruled out such a Camp David-style summit but insist existing interim agreements calling for three Israeli pullbacks in the West Bank must be carried out by the middle of next year in any event.
Israel and Egypt made peace in 1979 at Camp David, Maryland.
